concept.title: What is an Array Formula
concept.shortdesc: A brief description of what an array and an array formula is and in which situation you can use them.

conbody.p: A vector is a list of numbers that are either in a row or in a column. You then have a row vector or a column vector respectively. Excel does not use the term vector, but array. An array in Excel can be:

ul.li: A row of values (actually a row vector). This is a 1-dimensional horizontal matrix.
A column of values (actually a column vector). This is a 1-dimensional vertical matrix.
A rectangle of rows and columns of values, so an area. This is a 2 dimensional matrix.

conbody.p:
The following figure shows an example of each.
Array examples
Array examples

You can create a matrix with constant values as showed in the three examples, by starting in a cell with the = symbol and then placing a row of values between curly brackets {}. The values must be separated from each other by a special symbol. Which symbols to use as separator symbol depends on the language and regional settings on the computer.

ul.li:
English language systems
Comma , for a new column.
Semicolon ; for a new row.

Dutch language systems
Backslash \ for a new column.
Semicolon ; for a new row.

conbody.p: Furthermore, with a 2-dimensional array, you have to take into account:

ul.li: All rows must have the same number of columns.

conbody.p: The three examples are entered into Excel as follows.

={1,2,3,4,5} returns 1 row with 5 columns. 1-dimensional horizontal array
1-dimensional horizontal array

={1;3;6} returns 3 row with 1 column. 1-dimensional vertical array
1-dimensional vertical array

={1,2,3,4,5;3,5,7,9,11;6,9,12,15,18} returns 3 rows with 5 columns. 2-dimensional array
2-dimensional array

note.p: For all examples, only the first cell is editable. That is the cell where you entered the array. When you select another cell in the values area, the content in the formula bar is gray, and you cannot change the value.
